Description: The Nightwatch.js Framework aims to be a Node.js based End-to-End (E2E) testing solution for browser based apps and websites. It uses the Selenium WebDriver API to perform commands and assertions on DOM elements.

The Titanium framework aims to provide a platform for web developers to build cross-platform, native mobile applications using JavaScript. Currently, Titanium supports mobile smartphone operating systems such as Apple iPhone, Google's Android, and Mobile Web. Other platforms, such as Windows Phone, are currently in development.

The Moobile JavaScript Framework by Moobile aims to be a mobile application framework based on Mootools. The framework requires Safari or Chrome to be ultilized as well as a broiler plate for MooTools.

EmbedJS is a JavaScript framework that aims to be targeted at embedded devices (mobile phones, TVs, etc.). The frameworks offers a different approach by shipping just the code needed for each device. This feature results in less code going over the wire and branching at runtime as well as less memory usage.

Iconic JavaScript Framework by Iconic is currently free and open source. The framework aims to offer a library of mobile-optimized HTML, CSS and JS components, gestures, and tools for building highly interactive apps. It is built with Sass and optimized for AngularJS.
Zepto aims to be a minimalist JavaScript library/framework for modern browsers with a largely jQuery-compatible API. This requires Node.js installation prior to use.

jQTouch is a JavaScript plugin/framework that aims to work with either Zepto.js or jQuery, and includes animations, navigation, and themes for mobile WebKit browsers (as found in iOS, Android, BlackBerry, and WebOS). Features includes customization, theme support, callback functions, Zepto integration and many others.
PhoneGap JavaScript Framework aims to be an open source framework that allows developers to create mobile apps using standardized web APIs for platforms.
The Twelve-Space JavaScript Framework by Kevin Mack aims to be a Sass-based, BEM, OOCSS framework for creating DOM modules. This framework is written in JavaScript.

jQuery.my aims to be a plugin that binds HTML controls with underlying javascript object using declarative MVVM style manifest. Bindings are bi-directional and real-time. jQuery.my recognizes standard HTML controls as well as composite controls rendered by jQuery Mobile, nearly all jQuery UI widgets, Redactor, Ace, CodeMirror, Select2 and others.

ChocolateChip-UI aims to be a JavaScript framework for making mobile Web apps. It has three components: semantic HTML5 markup, CSS and JavaScript. Using the framework requires a familiarity with JavaScript so users can utilize features such as templates, Ajax requests and handle callbacks for user interaction. ChocolateChip-UI requires jQuery.

The RaptorJS aims to be a JavaScript module bundler that also provides first-level support for delivering JavaScript, CSS, images and other assets to the browser. Supported optimizations: Bundling, Code splitting, Lazy loading, Compression, and several others.

The Watir Framework aims to be an open-source (BSD) family of Ruby libraries for automating web browsers. It supports develper's apps regardless of the technology it is developed in. The framework supports testing in Internet Explorer on Windows, Firefox and Chrome on Windows, Mac and Linux.

Yeti aims to be a Framework that tests frameworks. It allows for the automation of testing for various test frameworks. Yeti attempts to test a dev box (where it works by itself) to a CI system (where it launches browsers with Selenium) without changing existing tests. The framework requires Node.js.

Zombie.js aims to be a lightweight framework for testing client-side JavaScript code in a simulated environment. Its biggest feature is that is does not require a browser for testing. Installation requires oi.js.

The aim of the Karma JavaScript Framework is to bring instant feedback testing to developers. Its features include: testing on real devices, remote workflow control, continuous integration, and others.

CasperJS aims to be a navigation scripting & testing utility for PhantomJS and SlimerJS. The framework facilitates the process of defining a full navigation scenario and provides functionality, methods & syntaxic sugar for doing common tasks. Such tasks include: defining and ordering navigantion steps; filing forms, clicking links, capturing screenshots, logging events and several others. This framework is written in JavaScript.

PhantomJS aims to be a headless WebKit that is scriptable with a JavaScript API. Its features include native support for various web standards: DOM handling, CSS selector, JSON, Canvas, and SVG. PhantomJS can be used to test workflow of various open-source projects: Bootstrap, CodeMirror, Ember.js, jQuery Mobile, Less.js, Modernizr, YUI3, and others. The framework is written in JavaScript.
The State Machine Framework offers developers a standalone javascript micro-framework that provides a finite state machine. This framework is written JavaScript.

The AngularJS JavaScript Router Framework by Angular-UI is a de-facto solution to flexible routing with nested views for the AngularJS API. This routing framework allows users to organize parts of interfaces into a state machine. The states are bound to named, nested and parallel views, allowing for powerful management of the user's application interfaces.
The AngularJS API allows developers to access and integrate the functionality of AngularJS with other applications and to create new applications.

The xCSS JavaScript Framework by Anton Pawlik aims to be a straightforward and object-oriented workflow when developing complex style cascades. It allows for developers to more easily develop and write CSS applications and includes a variety of other features.
The GroundworkCSS Framework allows for developers to use HTML5, CSS and Javascript toolkits. The Framework aims create accessible web apps that work on different devices.
The Unsematic CSS Framework by Nathan Smith aims to be a fluid grid for mobile, tablet, and desktop application developers.

The Tuktuk CSS Framework by Javi Jiménez allows for developers to create responsive front-end framework that creates extensible sites. Features include: CSS3 powered, and Object Oriented CSS: The aim of this framework is to encourage code reuse and create stylesheets that can be added to and maintained.
The Fluidable CSS Framework by Andri Sigurðsson aims to be a mobile first, responsive grid system. It is standalone, lightweight & built using LESS.
The Ink CSS Framework by SAPO aims to be an HTML5/CSS3 framework for design and prototyping.
The Kickoff CSS Framework by Kickoff aims to be a lightweight front-end framework for creating scalable, responsive sites.

The Cascade CSS Framework by John Slegers allows developers to split CSS into seperate files based on features rather than selectors as well as implementt a modifier design pattern inspired by SMACCS and OOCSS,
